items.title: Install Claude Code
items.note: Requires Node.js 18+. Works on macOS, Linux, and Windows (WSL). One command to install globally.

items.title: Launch interactive REPL
items.note: Opens the interactive session in your terminal. This is your primary interface.

items.title: Start with a prompt
items.note: Pass a prompt directly to skip the REPL and get an immediate result.

items.title: Check version
items.note: Always ensure you're on the latest version before a big session.

items.title: Update Claude Code
items.mac:
claude update
# or reinstall:
npm install -g @anthropic-ai/claude-code
items.win:
claude update
# or reinstall:
npm install -g @anthropic-ai/claude-code
items.note: Run regularly ‚Äî new features and bugfixes ship frequently.

items.title: Check health
items.note: Diagnoses installation, auth, and environment issues automatically.

items.title: Authenticate
items.note: Opens browser for OAuth. Required on first run or after token expiry.

items.title: Check auth status
items.note: Verify which account and plan you are authenticated with.

items.title: Stop Claude (stay in session)
items.note: Pauses Claude mid-response without closing the session. Never use Ctrl+C for this ‚Äî that exits everything.

items.title: Hard exit the REPL
items.note: Both fully exit Claude Code. Use Escape to just stop Claude without losing the session.

items.title: Rewind conversation
items.note: Double-tap Escape on blank input to browse and restore an earlier checkpoint. Resets chat context ‚Äî files on disk are unaffected.

items.title: Cycle permission modes
items.note: Normal ‚Üí Auto-accept edits (‚èµ‚èµ) ‚Üí Plan Mode (‚è∏). Mode shown bottom-right. With agent teams active, also cycles Delegate Mode.

items.title: New line (multi-line input)
items.note: Run /terminal-setup first to configure this binding in iTerm2, VS Code, or WezTerm. Default Enter submits the prompt.

items.title: Paste image from clipboard
items.note: Use Ctrl+V, not Cmd+V on Mac. Known quirk ‚Äî Cmd+V pastes text only. Ctrl+V pastes images from clipboard.

items.title: Open plan in editor
items.note: While in Plan Mode, opens the generated plan in your default text editor so you can edit before Claude proceeds.

items.title: Tab autocomplete
items.note: Autocomplete slash commands, file paths, and session names.

items.title: Navigate prompt history
items.note: Browse past prompts in the current session.

items.title: Jump to start / end of line
items.note: Bash-style readline navigation inside the Claude Code input field.

items.title: Move word forward / back
items.note: Mac: in iTerm2 go to Profiles ‚Üí Keys ‚Üí Left Option Key ‚Üí set to Esc+. Then Option+F/B jumps by word.

items.title: Delete previous word
items.note: Removes the word immediately before the cursor.

items.title: Clear input line
items.note: Clears the entire current input line without submitting.

items.title: Open PR in browser
items.note: After /install-github-app, PR links appear in the footer. Cmd-click (Mac) or Ctrl-click opens them in the browser. Requires gh CLI.

items.title: Drag file into terminal
items.note: Hold Shift while dragging a file into the terminal to reference it in Claude. Without Shift, VS Code/Cursor open it in a new tab instead.

items.title: /help
items.note: Show all available slash commands and keyboard shortcuts for your current environment.

items.title: /clear
items.note: Clear conversation history and start fresh. Use this every time you start a new task ‚Äî old context wastes tokens and confuses Claude.

items.title: /init
items.note: Generates CLAUDE.md by analyzing your codebase. The single most important setup step ‚Äî run it in every new project.

items.title: /model
items.note: Switch models mid-session without restarting. Sonnet for most tasks, Haiku for speed/cost, Opus for hard problems.

items.title: /context
items.note: Visualize current token usage. Monitor the context window before it gets auto-compacted.

items.title: /cost
items.note: Show token cost for the current session. Essential for monitoring API spend.

items.title: /resume
items.note: Opens an interactive session picker. Sessions stored per project/git repo. Press R in the picker to rename a session.

items.title: /memory
items.note: View and manage what Claude remembers from past sessions. Promote useful learnings into CLAUDE.md permanently.

items.title: /permissions
items.note: View and modify which tools Claude can use in the current session.

items.title: /sandbox
items.note: Enable file and network isolation to reduce permission prompts safely ‚Äî a safer alternative to --dangerously-skip-permissions.

items.title: /terminal-setup
items.note: Configures Shift+Enter and other key bindings for iTerm2, VS Code, WezTerm, and Ghostty.

items.title: /doctor
items.note: Check Claude Code installation health and diagnose configuration issues.

items.title: /config
items.note: Open the configuration panel to adjust Claude Code settings interactively.

items.title: /status
items.note: Show session info, model in use, and system status at a glance.

items.title: /install-github-app
items.note: Installs the GitHub app so Claude auto-reviews your PRs. Customize the generated claude-code-review.yml to focus on bugs and security only.

items.title: /exit
items.note: Exit the REPL cleanly.

items.title: Continue last session
items.note: Picks up right where you left off ‚Äî great for long refactoring or multi-step tasks across terminal restarts.

items.title: Resume by session ID
items.note: Resume a specific past session by its ID. Get IDs from the /resume picker.

items.title: Resume from PR
items.note: Resume or link a Claude Code session to a specific GitHub pull request number.

items.title: Print mode (non-interactive)
items.note: Executes prompt and exits ‚Äî perfect for scripting, CI pipelines, and piping output to other tools.

items.title: Pipe content into Claude
items.mac:
cat logs.txt | claude -p "explain these errors"
git diff | claude -p "write a commit message"
items.win:
type logs.txt | claude -p "explain these errors"
git diff | claude -p "write a commit message"
items.note: Claude reads stdin. Combine with grep, git diff, cat, etc. for powerful one-liners.

items.title: Start in Plan Mode
items.note: Launch directly in Plan Mode ‚Äî Claude explores and plans without making any file changes until you approve.

items.title: Select model at launch
items.mac:
claude --model claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929
claude --model claude-haiku-4-5-20251001
claude --model claude-opus-4-20250514
items.note: Pin a specific model version string for reproducibility in scripts and CI.

items.title: Add working directories
items.note: Include extra directories in Claude's working context ‚Äî essential for monorepos.

items.title: Output format
items.mac:
claude -p "query" --output-format json
claude -p "query" --output-format stream-json
claude -p "query" --output-format text
items.note: json and stream-json are ideal for CI pipelines that parse Claude's responses programmatically.

items.title: Verbose / debug output
items.note: Verbose logs all reasoning steps. Debug accepts comma-separated subsystem names: api, mcp, tools, hooks.

items.title: Skip permissions (trusted envs only)
items.note: ‚ö†Ô∏è Only for sandboxed / CI environments. Stops all permission prompts. Prefer /sandbox or wildcard permissions for team use.

items.title: Use as CI linter
items.mac:
# In package.json scripts:
"lint:ai": "claude -p 'Review git diff vs main. Output: file:line ‚Äî issue. No other text.'"
items.win: claude -p "Review git diff for bugs" --output-format json
items.note: Add Claude as a lint step in your CI/CD pipeline. Use --output-format json to parse results programmatically.

items.title: /clear between every task
items.note: Old conversation history eats tokens and confuses Claude on new tasks. Clear aggressively. Use ‚Üë arrow or /resume to revisit past sessions when needed.

items.title: Monitor token usage
items.note: Watch the token bar. When nearing the limit, Claude auto-compacts. You can preempt this with /clear + a brief summary to preserve quality.

items.title: Reference docs, don't embed them
items.mac:
# ‚úÖ In CLAUDE.md:
"For FooBarError, see ./docs/errors.md"

# ‚ùå Avoid:
@./docs/errors.md  (loads every session)
items.note: Referencing by path is token-efficient ‚Äî Claude reads the doc on demand. @-embedding loads the full file into every conversation whether you need it or not.

items.title: Keep CLAUDE.md under 150 lines
items.note: After ~150 lines, CLAUDE.md loses effectiveness. Use modular .claude/rules/*.md files for topic-specific instructions to keep it lean.

items.title: Use Skills for progressive disclosure
items.mac:
# Skills load on-demand (not every session):
.claude/skills/my-skill/SKILL.md

# Invoked with:
/my-skill
items.note: Skills replace @-file docs. Claude only loads skill content when invoked ‚Äî massive token savings vs. bloating CLAUDE.md with rarely-needed info.

items.title: Audit and limit MCP servers
items.mac:
claude mcp list
# Keep to 4‚Äì5 active servers max
items.note: Each MCP server's tool schema loads into your context window. 20k+ tokens of MCP leaves only ~20k for actual work. More MCP servers ‚â† better.

items.title: Rewind to restore earlier context
items.note: Choose an earlier message checkpoint. Claude resets its context to that point ‚Äî files on disk are unaffected. Great for undoing a bad direction.

items.title: Name sessions for findability
items.note: Default session names are timestamps. Rename to 'feature/auth-refactor' so you can find them days later.

items.title: Always plan before coding
items.mac:
"Explore the codebase, create a detailed plan,
then ask me to confirm before writing any code."
items.note: The Explore ‚Üí Plan ‚Üí Code ‚Üí Commit loop is the #1 pattern from Anthropic's own teams. Never let Claude jump straight to implementation on complex tasks.

items.title: Ask Claude to ask questions
items.mac:
"Before planning, ask me clarifying questions
about the requirements. Don't start coding yet."
items.note: Forces Claude to surface hidden assumptions before building. Results in dramatically better output. A single round of questions prevents hours of rework.

items.title: Write plan to plan.md
items.mac:
"Write your plan to plan.md first.
Use it as a checklist as you implement."
items.note: External plan files let you edit Claude's approach before it starts, track progress, and share context with parallel agents.

items.title: Use 'think hard' / 'ultrathink'
items.mac:
"Think hard before proposing a solution."
"Ultrathink through this architecture."
items.note: These phrases activate extended reasoning. Use sparingly ‚Äî they consume more tokens but dramatically improve output on hard problems. 'Ultrathink' > 'think hard' > nothing.

items.title: Reference files with @
items.mac:
@src/auth/login.py Fix the JWT expiry bug in validate_token()
@package.json What test runner is this project using?
items.note: The @ prefix loads a specific file into context. Always reference the exact file and function ‚Äî vague prompts produce vague results.

items.title: Paste URLs for live context
items.mac:
"Read https://github.com/org/repo/issues/84
and implement the fix described there."
items.note: Claude fetches URLs directly. Paste GitHub issues, API docs, Stack Overflow answers, or Figma design specs right into the prompt.

items.title: Drag screenshots for UI context
items.note: Visual context prevents misunderstandings on UI tasks. Drag a Figma export or mockup directly into the terminal.

items.title: Use ! prefix for shell commands
items.note: The ! prefix runs shell commands directly without a conversational turn. Faster and cheaper than asking Claude conversationally.

items.title: Always pair 'never' with an alternative
items.mac:
# ‚úÖ Do:
"Never use --foo-bar; prefer --baz instead"

# ‚ùå Don't:
"Never use --foo-bar"  (agent gets stuck)
items.note: Without an alternative, Claude gets stuck in loops trying to find a compliant path. Always pair a prohibition with what to do instead.

items.title: Use voice input for faster prompting
items.mac:
Use SuperWhisper, Apple Dictation,
or Whisper ‚Üí paste into Claude
items.win:
Use Windows Speech Recognition
or Whisper ‚Üí paste into Claude
items.note: Speaking is faster than typing for many developers. Whisper quietly with earphones in shared offices. Voice prompts tend to be more natural and complete.

items.title: Copy terminal output back to Claude
items.mac:
‚åò+A  then  ‚åò+C  in terminal
‚Üí paste into Claude with Ctrl+V
items.win:
Ctrl+A  then  Ctrl+C
‚Üí paste into Claude
items.note: Select all terminal output, copy, and paste back into Claude for analysis or debugging. Works for logs, build errors, test output ‚Äî any CLI output.

items.title: Generate with /init
items.note: Claude analyzes your codebase and generates a smart CLAUDE.md. Always do this first in a new project.

items.title: Global CLAUDE.md
items.note: Your personal coding style, preferred libraries, formatting rules. Applied to every project automatically.

items.title: Project CLAUDE.md
items.note: Project-specific: architecture overview, tech stack, testing approach, common commands. Commit to Git for team consistency.

items.title: Nested CLAUDE.md per subdirectory
items.mac:
frontend/CLAUDE.md   # React conventions
backend/CLAUDE.md    # API patterns
infra/CLAUDE.md      # Terraform rules
items.note: Claude loads the CLAUDE.md closest to the files it's editing. Perfect for monorepos with different tech in each folder.

items.title: What to include in CLAUDE.md
items.mac:
# ‚úÖ Great candidates:
- Common commands: npm test, make build
- Code style: functional components, ES modules
- Architecture: state in Zustand, see src/stores
- Testing: RTL required for all components
- What Claude repeatedly gets wrong (anti-patterns)
items.note: Document what Claude consistently gets wrong IN YOUR CODEBASE, not general best practices. That's where the real compounding value is.

items.title: Use Rules for modular instructions
items.note: Rules files let you scope instructions to specific file paths using frontmatter. Keeps CLAUDE.md lean while adding depth where needed.

items.title: Commit .claude/ directory to Git
items.mac:
git add .claude/ CLAUDE.md
git commit -m 'chore: add Claude Code config'
items.note: Share team settings, hooks, custom commands, and rules with your entire team. This is how you scale Claude Code across engineering.

items.title: Improve with /memory
items.note: Claude tracks learnings from sessions. Review with /memory and promote useful patterns into CLAUDE.md for permanent retention.

items.title: Escape stops, Ctrl+C exits
items.mac:
Escape  ‚Üí  stops Claude
‚åò+C or Ctrl+C  ‚Üí  exits session
items.win:
Escape  ‚Üí  stops Claude
Ctrl+C  ‚Üí  exits session
items.note: This is the most common gotcha for new users. Memorize it: Escape to pause, Ctrl+C to quit.

items.title: Explore ‚Üí Plan ‚Üí Code ‚Üí Commit
items.mac:
1. "Explore the codebase"
2. "Create a plan, ask me to confirm"
3. (confirm plan)
4. "Implement it"
5. git diff ‚Üí commit
items.note: This 5-step loop is the highest-ROI habit from Anthropic's internal engineering teams. Never skip the planning step on complex work.

items.title: Write tests, then implement
items.mac:
"Write tests for X first,
then implement X to make them pass."
items.note: Tests are the only reliable validation mechanism for AI-generated code. AI code often works superficially but has subtle bugs ‚Äî tests catch them.

items.title: Review every diff before committing
items.mac:
git diff
git diff --staged
git add -p  # stage hunks interactively
items.note: Never auto-commit AI work without reading the diff. Claude moves fast ‚Äî a 60-second review catches most mistakes before they hit your repo.

items.title: Use small, focused commits
items.mac: git commit -m 'fix: validate JWT expiry in auth.py'
items.note: Ask Claude to commit after each logical unit of work. Small commits are easier to revert, review, and understand than giant AI-generated dumps.

items.title: Document what Claude gets wrong
items.mac:
# In CLAUDE.md:
# ‚ö†Ô∏è Never use React.memo here ‚Äî causes flicker
# ‚úÖ Use useMemo instead. See src/hooks/useData.ts
items.note: Every time Claude makes the same mistake twice, add a corrective rule to CLAUDE.md. This is compounding value that makes Claude smarter over time in your codebase.

items.title: Use Plan Mode for risky changes
items.mac:
Shift+Tab  (cycle to Plan Mode)
# or at launch:
claude --permission-mode plan
items.note: In Plan Mode (‚è∏), Claude can read files and plan but cannot write anything. Approve the plan before switching to execute mode.

items.title: Run linters/formatters via hooks
items.mac:
# .claude/settings.json:
# PostToolUse hook runs black after every .py write
items.note: Automate post-write cleanup so Claude's output is always formatted. Configure once in settings.json and forget about it.

items.title: Prefer wildcard permissions over skip
items.note: Wildcard permissions are surgical and auditable. --dangerously-skip-permissions gives blanket access and belongs only in isolated CI sandboxes.

items.title: Use monorepos for large projects
items.mac:
# Single repo: schema + API + frontend
# Claude cross-references all three
items.note: Monorepos are ideal for LLMs. Claude can read the schema, API definitions, and implementation in one pass ‚Äî finding connections a human would miss.

items.title: Set notification on task completion
items.mac:
# iTerm2: Prefs ‚Üí Profiles ‚Üí Terminal
# ‚Üí Enable 'Send notification on idle'
# ‚Üí Lets you step away on long tasks
items.win: Use Windows notification via terminal emulator settings
items.note: For long-running Claude tasks, configure terminal notifications so you're alerted when Claude needs your input or finishes.

items.title: Create git worktrees for parallel agents
items.mac:
# Each worktree = isolated directory + branch:
git worktree add ../project-feat-a -b feature-a
git worktree add ../project-feat-b -b feature-b

# Open each in a separate terminal:
cd ../project-feat-a && claude
# (in another terminal)
cd ../project-feat-b && claude
items.note: Each worktree is a separate directory with its own files, sharing the same .git history. Each Claude instance works in complete isolation ‚Äî no conflicts.

items.title: Copy .env to each worktree
items.note: .env files are gitignored and don't carry over automatically. Always copy them before starting Claude in a new worktree.

items.title: Install deps in each worktree
items.mac:
cd ../project-feat-a && npm install
# pnpm is better ‚Äî symlinks shared packages:
cd ../project-feat-a && pnpm install
items.note: node_modules don't carry over. pnpm is strongly recommended for multi-worktree setups ‚Äî it symlinks packages and avoids duplicating gigabytes of dependencies.

items.title: Run multiple agents in VS Code panes
items.mac:
# Install Claude Code VS Code extension
# Open each worktree in its own pane/window
# Start 'claude' in each integrated terminal
items.note: The VS Code extension makes it easy to visually manage multiple parallel Claude instances. Each pane is a separate Claude session on a separate branch.

items.title: Spawn subagents with the Task tool
items.mac:
# In prompt or CLAUDE.md:
"Use the Task tool to spawn subagents
for each sub-component in parallel."
items.note: Claude Code's built-in Task tool lets a main agent orchestrate specialized subagents. Each gets its own focused context ‚Äî no cross-contamination.

items.title: Handoff via plan.md
items.mac:
# In Plan Mode prompt:
"Gather all context and write a comprehensive
plan.md ‚Äî include everything the next agent needs.
It will not have any other context."
items.note: When handing off between agents or sessions, force Claude to write a complete context dump to plan.md. The next agent reads it cold and hits the ground running.

items.title: Run autonomous tasks in containers
items.mac:
# --dangerously-skip-permissions is SAFE
# inside an isolated Docker container:
docker run -it --rm myimage \
  claude --dangerously-skip-permissions -p \
  "Execute PLAN.md end to end"
items.note: Long autonomous tasks (30+ min) belong in isolated containers or cloud sandboxes. Safe because the environment is fully disposable.

items.title: Clean up worktrees when done
items.mac:
git worktree remove ../project-feat-a
git worktree list  # verify cleanup
items.note: ‚ö†Ô∏è Forgotten worktrees accumulate fast and consume significant disk space (GBs on large repos with build artifacts). Clean up regularly.

items.title: Create project slash command
items.mac:
mkdir -p .claude/commands

# .claude/commands/review.md:
Review the changed files for bugs, security issues,
and performance problems. Be specific and concise.
items.note: Available to everyone in the project via /review. Commit to Git so the whole team benefits.

items.title: Create personal slash command
items.mac:
mkdir -p ~/.claude/commands

# ~/.claude/commands/daily.md:
Summarize what I worked on today from git log
and suggest tomorrow's top 3 priorities.
items.note: Personal commands in ~/.claude/commands are available across ALL your projects. Great for personal workflows.

items.title: Command with arguments
items.mac:
# .claude/commands/fix-issue.md:
Fix GitHub issue #$ARGUMENTS.
Read the issue, explore affected code,
implement a fix, and write a test.

# Usage:
/fix-issue 84
items.note: $ARGUMENTS is replaced by whatever you pass after the command name. Use $1, $2, $3 for positional arguments.

items.title: Command with frontmatter
items.mac:
---
description: Smart git commit
argument-hint: [optional message]
allowed-tools: Bash(git *)
---
Review staged changes with git diff --staged.
Then write a conventional commit message.
Optional context: $ARGUMENTS
items.note: Frontmatter controls metadata, Tab autocomplete hints, and pre-approved tools. The description shows in /help listings.

items.title: Use Skills (modern approach)
items.mac:
# Skills replace commands with extra power:
mkdir -p .claude/skills/deploy
# .claude/skills/deploy/SKILL.md

# Usage: /deploy
items.note: Skills support additional files, invocation control, and subagent execution. .claude/commands/ still works but Skills are the recommended modern pattern.

items.title: Anti-pattern: too many custom commands
items.mac:
# Aim for < 10 project commands
# If you have 15+, you've over-engineered it
items.note: "If you have a long list of complex custom slash commands, you've created an anti-pattern. The entire point is to type almost whatever you want and get useful results." ‚Äî Shrivu Shankar

items.title: Auto-format Python on write
items.note: Runs black + isort after every Python file write. Claude's output is always formatted before it sees the diff.

items.title: Run tests after edits
items.note: Automatically runs related unit tests after each write. Claude sees test failures and self-corrects without you having to ask.

items.title: Restrict permissions by pattern
items.note: Fine-grained allowlists + denylists with glob patterns. Deny takes precedence over allow. Put in .claude/settings.json for project-level control.

items.title: Enterprise: managed-settings.json
items.note: Enterprise teams: policies in managed-settings.json cannot be overridden by developers. Enforce security baselines org-wide.

items.title: 14 hook event types available
items.mac:
PreToolUse ¬∑ PostToolUse
PreFileWrite ¬∑ PostFileWrite
PreBashExec ¬∑ PostBashExec
... and 8 more
items.note: Hooks fire on specific tool events. Combine with lint scripts, notification tools, logging, and test runners for powerful automation pipelines.

items.title: Debug hook execution
items.note: Shows hook matching, command execution, output, and timing. Essential when hooks aren't firing as expected.

items.title: Add GitHub MCP (HTTP transport)
items.mac:
claude mcp add --transport http github \
  https://mcp.github.com
items.win: claude mcp add --transport http github https://mcp.github.com
items.note: Enables Claude to search repos, read issues, create PRs, and review code from inside any Claude Code session.

items.title: Add GitHub MCP (npx)
items.note: Alternative installation via npx. The -- separator tells Claude to run the rest as a subprocess command.

items.title: Add Playwright MCP (browser automation)
items.mac:
claude mcp add -s user playwright \
  npx @playwright/mcp@latest
items.win: claude mcp add -s user playwright npx @playwright/mcp@latest
items.note: Lets Claude control a real browser: take screenshots, fill forms, run end-to-end tests. Highly recommended as a daily companion.

items.title: List MCP servers
items.note: Verify which MCP servers are configured and active. Audit regularly ‚Äî each server consumes tokens from your context window.

items.title: Debug MCP connections
items.note: Shows connection status, available tools, and error details for all configured MCP servers.

items.title: Keep MCP footprint minimal
items.mac:
# Rule of thumb: 4‚Äì5 servers max
# Each server schema = tokens consumed
items.note: "If you're using 20k+ tokens of MCPs, you're crippling Claude. That leaves only ~20k tokens for actual work." More MCP servers is not better.

items.title: Use Gemini CLI as web fallback
items.mac:
# Create a skill routing blocked URLs
# to Gemini CLI (broader web access)
# ~/.claude/skills/web-fallback/SKILL.md
items.note: Claude's WebFetch can't access some sites (Reddit, etc.). A custom skill can invoke Gemini CLI as a fallback for content Claude can't fetch directly.

items.title: Sonnet 4.5 ‚Äî Best default
items.note: Best default for most coding tasks. Strong reasoning, efficient token use. Recommended for Pro and Max plans. Use for 80%+ of work.

items.title: Haiku 4.5 ‚Äî Fast & cheap
items.note: Fastest and most affordable. Use for simple, repetitive tasks: renaming, formatting, boilerplate. Ideal for CI pipelines.

items.title: Opus 4.5 ‚Äî Most capable
items.note: Maximum capability. Reserve for complex architecture, hard debugging, and multi-step reasoning. Costs more ‚Äî use intentionally.

items.title: Switch model mid-session
items.note: No restart needed. Switch to a cheaper model for easy follow-up tasks after a hard planning phase.

items.title: Launch with pinned model version
items.note: Pin exact version strings in CI scripts for reproducibility.

items.title: Set effort level for hard tasks
items.note: Activates extended thinking. Use for architecture reviews, security audits, and complex debugging sessions.

items.title: Headless mode in scripts
items.mac:
claude -p "Review this diff for security issues" < diff.txt
git diff | claude -p "write a commit message"
items.note: The -p flag makes Claude non-interactive ‚Äî perfect for cron jobs, build scripts, and automated pipelines.

items.title: JSON output for parsing
items.note: Use json or stream-json output format to parse Claude's responses programmatically in CI systems.

items.title: GitHub Actions integration
items.mac:
# .github/workflows/claude-review.yml:
jobs:
  review:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v3
      - run: npm install -g @anthropic-ai/claude-code
      - run: |
          git diff HEAD~1 | \
          claude -p 'Review for bugs and security' \
          --output-format json > review.json
        env:
          ANTHROPIC_API_KEY: ${{ secrets.ANTHROPIC_API_KEY }}
items.note: Add ANTHROPIC_API_KEY as an encrypted GitHub Actions secret. Never hardcode API keys.

items.title: Set API key as environment variable
items.mac:
export ANTHROPIC_API_KEY=sk-ant-...
# Add to ~/.zshrc or ~/.bashrc to persist
items.note: Claude Code reads ANTHROPIC_API_KEY automatically. In CI, add it as an encrypted secret.

items.title: Auto-review PRs on push
items.mac:
# 1. Run: /install-github-app
# 2. Customize the generated file:
# .github/claude-code-review.yml
direct_prompt: |
  Review for bugs and security issues only.
  Be concise. Skip style and nitpicks.
items.note: After setup, Claude reviews every PR automatically. Edit the yml ‚Äî default reviews are too verbose and nitpick style issues.
